Actually, yes, they do have explanations. Here are a couple with which I am familiar.
 
 God created the light from the distant stars on it's way to earth. Now I'm not clear when the light was created that we see as stars. Light was created on the first day and the sun and the moon and the stars were created on the 4th day (and hung in the firmament). Now that means, of course, that the history of events that we see in the light from the stars never really happened. It is a false history that god created just to fool us. He just made the universe look old. And example of the above is SN 1987 A. It has been measured by more than one method to be 170,000 light years away. That means that it actually never existed and that the fading star (it is almost invisible now) was never there and the shock wave that is lighting a ring (now at it's brightest), was never illuminated by that shock wave. The light from those events was created 164,000 years after they appear to have happened.
 
 Another explanation is that the speed of light has been slowing down. Barry Setterfield of Australia is the proponent of this. He took many of the historical measurments of the speed of light (all relatively recent, you know. First done in 1676.), plotted them on an exponential curve and concluded light was much faster in the past and has just now, when we have developed the technology to measure it precisely, stabilized at the current speed. Now as I understand it, there is no good reason to plot the data on an exponential curve except to cram 13.7 billion years of travel of light into 6000 years. I also understand that Setterfield left out some of the measurments. When they are included, the data point to a different finding. Besides that, the speed of light is one of those nasty little constants that tend to change the laws of physics when you mess with them. You might guess that relativity becomes a pure muddle when you change the speed of light as well as other principles of physics. I believe that it was Maxwell, while working on his theory that eventually united electricity and magnetism found that the speed of propagation of electromagnetic waves was a consequence of his equations. That was in the 1860s. And Einstein discovered that Maxwell's equations were not compatible with Galileo/Newton mechanics. Someone was wrong. Relativity says that it was Galileo/Newton.
 
 And yet another explanation is that the Bible says that god stretched the firmament. Now the actual reference from the Bible is to the stretching of a tent. God stretched the firmament over the earth like a tent. But never mind. Creationists sometimes claim that this means that god created the universe quite small and then stretched it. Thus the light was created close enough to reach earth in a short time but now appears far away because god stretched the universe.
 
 And finally there are those who claim that light at extremes of the universe travels faster. In other words, the farther that one goes away from earth, the faster light is traveling. One problem with this is that if that were true, then events at great distances would appear to go in slow motion. And that isn't true. For example, various phenomena in SN 1987 A have been observed (predicted and then observed actually) that indicate that light at 170,000 light years distance is traveling at the same speed as on earth.
 
 None of these are based on any evidence or any actual science. I heard an interesting math problem once that might back up a couple of the arguments being put out by the creationists. 
 
 You come into a room where there is a 100 gallon aquarium filling up with water from a sink. The aquarium is filled with 40 gallons of water and is currently filling at a rate of 2 gallons per minute. How long has the aquarium been filling?
 
 While many will say that it has been 20 minutes. However, it is really a trick question. Since there was no one observing the experiment taking place, a prankster was able to sneak into the lab and decrease the flow of water from 5 gallons per minute to 2 gallons per minute when 10 gallons were in the tank.
 
 So maybe some constants aren't so constant after all . . .

To use your analogy, this is a bit like having a video recording of the past twenty minutes of the tank filling up. Now of course some prankster might have filmed the tank filling, emptied it, half filled it, then set the tap running all to make it look like it had been filling for the past twenty minutes...

Unfortunately for you, Nallyo, your analogy doesn't match what is going on in cosmology.
 
 We know the speed of light hasn't changed because the emission spectrums in stars observed across the full range of ages match those observable on earth now. This could not happen if the speed of light had changed.
 
 The same thing happens in Geology, sudden changes produce effects - effects we could observe but don't, while slow changes produce other effects - effects we could observe and do.
 
 The water on the other hand is non-destinct, it produces an amorphous slosh with no features from which to observe the rate of flow (although I suppose it might be possible to deduce it from water tempreture or splash patterns?).

Also you could technically measure the original amount, and then the dripped amount, and compare them for evaporation. You could measure the sediment according to density, the saturation of trace elements, the stage of solutes. You could measure the ambient humidity before and after. Really, there are many possibilities.
 
 This is actually a great example, in retrospect. The Creationist is like a guy who is convinced by a letter from an expert he respects that it was done in 20 minutes. The evolutionist is the person who notes the amount of sediment, the mineral crystallization around the edges of the water, etc., and takes a closer look- only to find that the evidence points to a period of several days or weeks.
 
 There's not much that an inquiring mind and a little research can't uncover.

Who said the earth is only 10,000 years old? 
 
 The translation of "days" in Genesis is usually taken to mean that God created the earth in six 24 hour periods (or "earth days"). However, this is most likely an incorrect translation.
 
 The book of Genesis was written in Hebrew, which has very few words to describe things (about 3,000). The word used to define a time period was "Yom" which could mean day, or any defined period of time.
 
 Because scientific evidence points to an earth that is much, much older than 10,000 years, it is only logical that the earth was created in 6 "stages", not 6 "days".

Who said the earth is only 10,000 years old?

 
 But the problem is that it is popular belief that the earth was created 10,000 years ago or less. Science may show one thing but religious believe another thing. How often this happens.

But the problem is that it is popular belief that the earth was created 10,000 years ago or less. Science may show one thing but religious believe another thing. How often this happens.

 
 Yes, many Christians believe the earth is about 10,000 years old. But that doesn't make it a biblical truth. The age of the earth is not stated in the Bible -- so no matter how old or young it is, it will never contradict the bible.

The book of Genesis was written in Hebrew, which has very few words to describe things (about 3,000). The word used to define a time period was "Yom" which could mean day, or any defined period of time.

 
 This is both true and false. Yom has a very similar meaning to our own word 'day' which can also mean any defined period of time - "in our father's day", etc. However, in the same way that day only has that meaning under special circumstances obvious from the context, Yom also needs special context to not mean a literal day.
 
 The use of Yom in the Genesis account unambiguously means a literal day, the hebrew word use and order has no other interpretation.

Can creationists explain why we can see stars millions of light years away? Do creationists have a valid reason for claiming astronomers/physicists have got it wrong?

 
 I have been reading some of the replies on this page, and yes there is a very new valid way that creationists can explain the fact that we see stars that are billions of light years away in a universe that is thousands of years old. This problem is appearently solved by Dr Russell Humphreys new "Relativistic Cosmology" in which he out lines in the book "Starlight and Time." 
 
 I got this book a few days ago, and I am now nearly finished reading it. On page 11 he briefly out lines where he is heading in regards to his theory. His new cosmology uses exactly the same sciences and equations as the big bang theory, i.e. that of General Relativity (GR). According to Einstein's theory of General Relativity, gravity affects the flow of time. Clocks at a low altitude tick more slowly than clocks at a high altitude - and this has been observationly confirmed. For example, an atomic clock at the Royal Observatory in Greenwich, England, ticks five microseconds per year slower than an identical clock at the National Bureau of Standards in Boulder, Colorado, both clocks being accurate to about one microsecond per year. The difference is exactly what GR predicts for the one-mile difference in alitude. Both the clocks are "correct" in their own frame of reference, it all depends on where you are in relation to a gravitational field. The effect applies to the rates of all physical processes and biological "clocks". 
 
 He than goes on to say what this new cosmology shows is that gravitational time distortion in the early universe would have meant that while a few days were passing on Earth, billions of years would have been available for light to travel to Earth. It still means that God made the heavens and Earth in six ordinary days, only a few thousand years ago. It then has to be asked to which frame of reference is the six days related to? The mathematics of this new theory shows that while God makes the universe in six days in Earth's frame of reference, the light has ample time in the extra-terrestrial frame of reference to travel the required distances. 
 
 Dr Russell Humphreys uses the big bang equations, i.e. the equations of GR to show that all of this could have been possible. The crucial reason why such different cosmologies (i.e. New Cosmology and big bang) come out of the same mathematics is that two different (but absolutely arbitrary) starting points (initial assumptions) are utilized. The big bang theory says that the universe has no edge and no centre, and that 3-D spacec expands with matter, i.e. it is unbounded. Why do big bang cosmologists use as their starting point the assumption (which seems quite contrary to common sense) that the universe has no boundary? Is there some good scientific reason, or is it perhaps demanded or even suggested by well-established, experimentally-backed theory, like GR? The answer is no. It is an arbitrary assumptino, called the "cosmological principle", or more recently the "Copernican principle". This assumes that there is no edge and no center. ~ The above came from p.18.
 
 So we know that unbounded cosmos (arbitrary assumption) + Cosmos has expanded (observations) + General Relativity = Big Bang Cosmology.
 
 BUT!!! Bounded cosmos (Biblically based assumption) + Cosmos has expanded (observations) + General Relativity = White Hole Cosmology.
 
 This is how Dr Humphreys goes on to explain it without the mathematical stuff. Imagine this bounded universe when it was about fifty times smaller than today. The equations of GR would then allow the universe to be in one of two states (no other states are possilbe). One of the possiblities would put the universe inside a huge black hole. Matter and light can exist inside a black hole; however, the equations of GR require that they must fall inward, eventually reaching the point of "singularity" at the center. However, the evidence indicates that the universe has expanded (red shift of starlight) and is not currently undergoing such an overall inward-falling. Therefore the universe cannot now be within a black hole. 
 
 The other possibility allowed by GR is that th euniverse was previously in a huge white hole. This is a black hole running in reverse. Astrophysicists of the 1970's gave that name to the concept, arising from theoretical studies of black holes. The concept is still considered valid today. Like a black hole, however, a white hole would also have an event horizon. Matter and light could exist inside its event horizon without any particular problems, as they would be no singularity at its center. However, the equations of GR must require that light and matter inside the event horizon of a white hole must expand outward. The event horizon of a white hole would be a one-way border which permits only outward motion  through itself. Matter and light waves would have to move out of a white hole, but they could not go back in. Since the diameter of an event horizon is proportional to the amount of matter inside it, the event horizon would shrink as matter passes through it and out of a white hole. As more matter passes out of the white hole the event horizon would get smaller and smaller and eventually shrink to nothing. There would then be no more white hole, but only scattered matter moving away from a central point. 
 
 The ideas about black and white holes comes directly from GR. The equatinos of GR permit, but do not demand, the existence of white holes today. By starting with the assumption that the universe is bounded and accepting the overwhelming observational evdience that it has expanded, it can be shown:
 1. The visible universe was once inside an event horizon. 
 The means that it was once either within a black hole or a white hole. We have seen that if it were a black hole it would be contracting, which is not indicated by the evidence. Therefore:
 2. The visible universe was once inside a white hole.
 It may, however, have commenced as a black hole before expansion started. 
 
 Dr Russell Humphreys than goes through and describes a possible scenario as to how the Creation Week might have unfolded. His new theory also answers how the CMB (Cosmic Microwave Background) may have been formed. He believes that it may have happened on Day Two of the Creation Week. By taking that Bible literally, and applying GR and science, he has shown that the light from distant stars can arrive to Earth in a single day, Earth Standard Time (E.S.T). He says and I quote in relation to the stars being made:
 "Early on the fourth morning, God coalesces the clusters of atoms into stars and thermonuclear fusion ignites in them. The newly-formed stars find themselves grouped together in galaxies and clusters of galaxies. As the fourth day proceeds on Earth, the more distant stars age billions of years, while their light also has the same billions of years to travel to the Earth. While the light is on its way, space continues to expand, relativistically stretching out the light waves and shifting the wavelengths toward the red side of the spectrum. Stars which are now farthest away have the greatest redshift, because the waves have been streched the most. This progressive redshift is exactly what is observed. 
 
 For more information I would strongly suggest and urge you to get Dr Humphreys book "Starlight and Time". It is a thrilling application of science and mathematics and is hard to put down.

 The Law of Causality, or "cause and effect" relationship states that one cause can have many effects, but no effect can be quantitatively greater r qualitatively superior to its cause. Observed effects are assumed to ave causes because of this Law, and are not treated as purely random or chance occurences. The inquisitive mind will speculate on the cause of an observed effect and then seek to recreate and test the cause experimentally. [Jeremy I. All of these achievements involve doing experiments in the present, making inferences from the results and doing more experiments to test those ideas. Here the inferences, or conclusions, are closely related to the experiments and there is often little room for speculation. This type of science is called process, or operational science, and has given us many wonderful advances in knowledge that benefited mankind. 
 However, there is another type of science that deals with the pasts, which can be called historical or origins science. When it comes to working out what happened in the past, science is limited because we cannot do experiments directly on past events, and history cannot be repeated. In origins science, observations made in the present are used to make inferences about the past. THe experiments that can be done in the present that relate to the past are often quite limited, so the inferences require a deal of guess work. The further in the past being studied the longer the chain of inferences involved, i.e. more guess work, and there is more room for non-scientific factors to influence the conclusions (such as religious belief (or unbelief) of the scientist). But is it science? Science has given us many wonderful things: men on the moon, cheap food, modern medicine, electricity, computers, and so on. All of these achievements involve doing experiments in the present, making inferences from the results and doing more experiments to test those ideas. Here the inferences, or conclusions, are closely related to the experiments and there is often little room for speculation. This type of science is called process, or operational science, and has given us many wonderful advances in knowledge that benefited mankind. 
 However, there is another type of science that deals with the pasts, which can be called historical or origins science. When it comes to working out what happened in the past, science is limited because we cannot do experiments directly on past events, and history cannot be repeated. In origins science, observations made in the present are used to make inferences about the past. THe experiments that can be done in the present that relate to the past are often quite limited, so the inferences require a deal of guess work. The further in the past being studied the longer the chain of inferences involved, i.e. more guess work, and there is more room for non-scientific factors to influence the conclusions (such as religious belief (or unbelief) of the scientist). So what may be presented as "science" regarding the past may be little more than the scientist's own personal world view. Does this make sense to you? The conflicts between "science" and "religion" occur in this historical science, not in operational science (including sciences like genetics). Unfortunately, the respect earned by the successses of operational science confounds many into thinking that the conjectural claims arising from origins science carry the same authority. When it comes to historical science, it is not so much the evidence in the present that is debated, but the inferences about the past. Scientists who believe the Bible will come to a different conclusion about the past from those who ignore the Bible. Do you follow this? It is this wilful denial of God's Word that lies at the root of many disagreements over "historical science".

Not true. Most of your body's functionality carries on just fine without influence from the concious aspects of your brain. They are controlled via the brain stem. OK that is still the brain, but it's not the full story. The gut has it's own nervous system: the enteric nervous system that is at least as complex as that of the spinal cord. It acts largely independently of the brain and spine. Also there is your imune system that also acts largely independently of the brain.
 
 It's a poor analogy to view the brain as say a CPU in a computer, controlling it's every move. A better anology is to think of the body as a concert. The brain acts as a conductor of the orchestra: each organ pl,ays it's own tune and the brain coordinates them, keeping them in harmony. The anaology can be stretched a bit more to have the enteric nervous system and the immune system controlling the threaters lights and manning the bar during the interval, ie when they do there jobs is determined by the conductor, but having been activated, they then act out their own roles independently.
